pageData.text: In this activity, a microscope will be used to examine onion root tip cells and whitefish cells at various stages of the cell cycle. Provided photos and descriptions of the stages of the cell cycle can be used to identify cells that are undergoing <button class='glossary-text'>mitosis</button>. Comparisons of whitefish and onion cells will then be made. Optional extension activities involve the use of Animal Histology and Plant Histology apps for the iPad<sup>®</sup>/iPhone<sup>®</sup> to study the cell cycle.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Hard-sided container (e.g., a small, sturdy cardboard box)

pageData.subTitle: Overview video: Cell Cycle and Mitosis

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Use a microscope to observe phases of <button class='glossary-text'>mitosis</button> and the cell cycle in plant and animal cells.
Explain the different phases of the cell cycle, including the phases of mitosis.
Identify the phase of mitosis based on the arrangement of chromosomes.

pageData.text: Multicellular organisms grow and develop as their cells go through the cell cycle and <button class='glossary-text'>mitosis</button>, which allows each cell to replicate itself. In some organisms, such as starfish and salamanders, mitosis can regenerate an entire limb. Scientists hope that such regeneration could be triggered in humans, providing an alternative to prosthetics for millions worldwide who have lost limbs, either due to injury or a birth defect.

Although such regeneration is not yet possible, a breakthrough in frogs demonstrates a step in the right direction<sup>1</sup>. A group of African clawed frogs were given a cocktail of drugs via a wearable bioreactor within the first 24 hours of leg amputation. The drugs facilitated various cellular responses, such as inhibition of inflammation and collagen production (to reduce scarring), and growth promotion of nerves, blood vessels, and muscle fibers. 18 months after the treatment, the frogs had grown legs that, while not aesthetically perfect, were almost fully functional in allowing the frogs to stand and swim.

Reference 1Sloat, S. (2022, January 26). Can humans regrow limbs? A lab study with frogs offers hope. NBC News. https://www.nbcnews.com/science/science-news/can-humans-regrow-limbs-lab-study-frogs-offers-hope-rcna13645

pageData.desc: A frog in a body of water.
pageData.altText: A frog in a body of water.

pageData.text: The ability of organisms to reproduce their own kind is the one characteristic that best distinguishes living things from nonliving matter. The continuity of life is based on the reproduction of cells, or <button class='glossary-text'>cell division</button>. Cell division functions in reproduction, growth, and repair.

In terms of reproduction, the division of a unicellular organism reproduces an entire organism, thereby increasing the population. Cell division on a larger scale can produce progeny for some multicellular organisms (e.g., organisms such as plants capable of growth from cuttings). For growth, cell division enables a multicellular organism to develop from a single fertilized egg or <button class='glossary-text'>zygote</button>. In a multicellular organism, cell division functions in the repair and renewal of cells that die from normal wear and tear or accidents.

Cell division is an integral part of the cell cycle, which is defined as the life of a cell from its origin at the division of a parent cell until its own division into two cells. A dividing cell duplicates its DNA, distributes the two copies to opposite ends of the cell, and then splits into two daughter cells.

pageData.subTitle: Interphase
pageData.text: The cell cycle is divided into <button class='glossary-text'>Interphase</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>Mitosis</button> (M) phase (Figure 1). Interphase accounts for about 90% of the cell cycle and is divided into three subphases: the <button class='glossary-text'>G1 phase</button> (“first gap”), the <button class='glossary-text'>S phase</button> (“synthesis”), and the <button class='glossary-text'>G2 phase</button> (“second gap”). The daughter cells may then repeat the cycle.

During all three subphases, the cell grows by producing proteins and cytoplasmic organelles such as mitochondria and the endoplasmic reticulum. When a cell is not dividing, each chromosome is in the form of a long, thin chromatin fiber. Chromosome duplication occurs only during the S phase; after that, each duplicated chromosome consists of two sister chromatids that contain identical copies of the chromosome’s DNA.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: This picture shows a pie chart diagram of the different phases of the cell cycle. There is a circular border shaded in black, that shows “Interphase” surrounding 3 pieces of the pie chart (~85% of the chart). The 3 pieces are the G1 phase, where rapid growth and metabolic activity occur and centrioles replicate, which is shaded in yellow and taking up about 35% of the chart; the S phase, where growth and DNA synthesis occur, which is shaded in blue and taking up a little over 25% of the chart; the G2 phase, where growth and final preparations for division occur, which is shaded in green and taking up about 20% of the chart. The rest of the circular border (the remaining ~15% across the bottom) is shaded in white and shows the “Mitosis” stage, which surrounds 4 small slices of the chart (~3.5% of the pie chart each), with each stage labeled as follows: telophase, anaphase, metaphase, and prophase.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: This picture shows a pie chart diagram of the different phases of the cell cycle. There is a circular border shaded in black, that shows “Interphase” surrounding 3 pieces of the pie chart (~85% of the chart). The 3 pieces are the G1 phase, where rapid growth and metabolic activity occur and centrioles replicate, which is shaded in yellow and taking up about 35% of the chart; the S phase, where growth and DNA synthesis occur, which is shaded in blue and taking up a little over 25% of the chart; the G2 phase, where growth and final preparations for division occur, which is shaded in green and taking up about 20% of the chart. The rest of the circular border (the remaining ~15% across the bottom) is shaded in white and shows the “Mitosis” stage, which surrounds 4 small slices of the chart (~3.5% of the pie chart each), with each stage labeled as follows: telophase, anaphase, metaphase, and prophase.

pageData.text: By late <button class='glossary-text'>interphase</button>, a nuclear membrane still surrounds the nucleus, which contains one or more nucleoli. The chromosomes have been duplicated but cannot be seen individually because they have not yet condensed. The centrosome has replicated to form two centrosomes, and in animal cells, each centrosome features two centrioles.

Upon completion of Interphase, actual division of the cell occurs in the M phase. The M phase consists of two stages: <button class='glossary-text'>mitosis</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>cytokinesis</button>.

Mitosis, which involves division of the nucleus, is a continuum of changes; however, for convenience, mitosis is usually divided into five subphases: <button class='glossary-text'>prophase</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>prometaphase</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>metaphase</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>anaphase</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>telophase</button>. Cytokinesis is the division of the cytoplasm and usually overlaps the telophase mitotic subphase.

pageData.question: Which of the following events in a multicellular organism is possible because of cell division?

options.text: A multicellular organism develops from a single-cell zygote.
A new offspring is produced in one cell cycle.
The cells in the organism adhere to one another to form organs.
Each cell can reproduce into three identical daughter cells.
The organism can enter a state of suspended animation.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Cell division facilitates growth and enables a multicellular organism to develop from a fertilized egg (zygote) that is a single cell.

pageData.question: Which of the following statements about the cell cycle is true?

options.text: Interphase is the longest phase of the cell cycle.
DNA is synthesized in each subphase of interphase.
The actual division of the cell occurs in interphase.
The cell pauses all cellular activity during the gap phases.
The M phase consists of 3 subphases.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Interphase is longest stage and accounts for about 90% of the cell cycle.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Cell division is an integral part of the cell cycle, which is defined as the life of a cell from its origin at the division of a parent cell until its own division into two cells. A dividing cell duplicates its DNA, distributes the two copies to opposite ends of the cell, and then splits into two daughter cells. In terms of reproduction, the division of a unicellular organism reproduces an entire organism, thereby increasing the population. Cell division on a larger scale can produce progeny for some multicellular organisms (e.g., organisms such as plants capable of growth from cuttings). For growth, cell division enables a multicellular organism to develop from a single fertilized egg or zygote. In a multicellular organism, cell division functions in the repair and renewal of cells that die from normal wear and tear or accidents. The cell cycle is divided into Interphase and the Mitosis (M) phase (Figure 1). Interphase accounts for about 90% of the cell cycle and is divided into three subphases: the G1 phase (“first gap”), the S phase (“synthesis”), and the G2 phase (“second gap”). Upon completion of interphase, actual division of the cell occurs in the M phase.

hintData.body: Cell division is an integral part of the cell cycle, which is defined as the life of a cell from its origin at the division of a parent cell until its own division into two cells. A dividing cell duplicates its DNA, distributes the two copies to opposite ends of the cell, and then splits into two daughter cells. In terms of reproduction, the division of a unicellular organism reproduces an entire organism, thereby increasing the population. Cell division on a larger scale can produce progeny for some multicellular organisms (e.g., organisms such as plants capable of growth from cuttings). For growth, cell division enables a multicellular organism to develop from a single fertilized egg or zygote. In a multicellular organism, cell division functions in the repair and renewal of cells that die from normal wear and tear or accidents. The cell cycle is divided into Interphase and the Mitosis (M) phase (Figure 1). Interphase accounts for about 90% of the cell cycle and is divided into three subphases: the G1 phase (“first gap”), the S phase (“synthesis”), and the G2 phase (“second gap”). Upon completion of interphase, actual division of the cell occurs in the M phase.

img.alt: Figure 1: This picture shows a pie chart diagram of the different phases of the cell cycle. There is a circular border shaded in black, that shows “Interphase” surrounding 3 pieces of the pie chart (~85% of the chart). The 3 pieces are the G1 phase, where rapid growth and metabolic activity occur and centrioles replicate, which is shaded in yellow and taking up about 35% of the chart; the S phase, where growth and DNA synthesis occur, which is shaded in blue and taking up a little over 25% of the chart; the G2 phase, where growth and final preparations for division occur, which is shaded in green and taking up about 20% of the chart. The rest of the circular border (the remaining ~15% across the bottom) is shaded in white and shows the “Mitosis” stage, which surrounds 4 small slices of the chart (~3.5% of the pie chart each), with each stage labeled as follows: telophase, anaphase, metaphase, and prophase.

pageData.subTitle: Prophase
pageData.text: Within the <button class='glossary-text'>prophase</button> nucleus, the nucleoli disappear and chromatin fibers become more tightly coiled, condensing into discrete chromosomes that can be observed with a light microscope. Each duplicated chromosome appears as two identical sister chromatids, each of which contains an identical copy of the chromosome’s DNA. As the chromosomes condense, the region where the chromatids connect shrinks to a narrow area, known as the centromere. Outside the nucleus, the mitotic spindle begins to form, which is composed of centrosomes and the microtubules that extend from them. The radial arrays of shorter microtubules that extend from the centrosomes are called asters. The centrosomes move away from each other, apparently propelled by lengthening of the microtubules between them.

pageData.subTitle: Prometaphase
pageData.text: In <button class='glossary-text'>prometaphase</button>, the nuclear envelope disappears and the microtubules extending from each centrosome can now invade the nuclear area to interact with the condensed chromosomes.

pageData.subTitle: Metaphase
pageData.text: At the start of <button class='glossary-text'>metaphase</button>, the centrosomes are at opposite poles of the cell. The spindle fibers push the sister chromatids until their centromeres are all arranged at the metaphase plate, an imaginary plane equidistant from the poles that defines metaphase.

pageData.subTitle: Anaphase
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Anaphase</button> is the shortest stage of <button class='glossary-text'>mitosis</button>. It begins when the connection between the sister chromatids is cleaved, allowing the two sister chromatids of each pair to separate. Each chromatid has now become a fullfledged chromosome. Each chromatid is pulled, centromere first, toward the pole to which it is attached by spindle fibers. The cell begins to elongate, and by the end of anaphase, the two poles have an equivalent collection of chromosomes.

pageData.subTitle: Telophase
pageData.text: At <button class='glossary-text'>telophase</button>, the chromosomes become less tightly coiled. Daughter nuclei begin to form at the two poles when nuclear envelopes arise from the fragments of the parent cell’s nuclear envelope and other portions of the endomembrane system. Additionally, the nucleoli begin to form. Mitosis, the division of one nucleus into two genetically identical nuclei, is now complete.

pageData.subTitle: Cytokinesis
pageData.text: The cytoplasm divides in a process known as <button class='glossary-text'>cytokinesis</button>, which is well underway by late <button class='glossary-text'>telophase</button>, so the two daughter cells appear shortly after the end of <button class='glossary-text'>mitosis</button>. In animal cells, cytokinesis involves the formation of a cleavage furrow, which in essence pinches the cell in two. Conversely, in plant cells, vesicles derived from the Golgi apparatus produce a cell plate at the middle of the cell that eventually forms the new cell wall. Cytokinesis completes <button class='glossary-text'>cell division</button> and the M phase of the cell cycle.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Interphase occurs before mitosis as preparation for nuclear division.

pageData.question: In which step of the cell cycle are two daughter cells formed?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Cytokinesis is the division of the cytoplasm and its contents into two daughter cells.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Mitosis is the division of the nuclear material within a somatic cell (any cell not designed for sexual reproduction) and is the first step of cellular division by which one parent cell divides, creating two genetically identical daughter cells. Prophase is the first phase of mitosis. During this phase, replicated DNA condenses into chromosomes that consist of two identical sister chromatids bound by a centromere. The nuclear membrane begins to disappear as it breaks down. Metaphase is the shortest phase of mitosis. During anaphase, the microtubules pull sister chromatids toward opposite sides of the cell. Each chromatid is now properly referred to as a chromosome. As telophase begins, a visible nuclear membrane begins to form around each set of chromosomes. In the last step, division of the cytoplasm occurs, and its contents are split into two daughter cells.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Mitosis is the division of the nuclear material within a somatic cell (any cell not designed for sexual reproduction) and is the first step of cellular division by which one parent cell divides, creating two genetically identical daughter cells. Prophase is the first phase of mitosis. During this phase, replicated DNA condenses into chromosomes that consist of two identical sister chromatids bound by a centromere. The nuclear membrane begins to disappear as it breaks down. Metaphase is the shortest phase of mitosis. During anaphase, the microtubules pull sister chromatids toward opposite sides of the cell. Each chromatid is now properly referred to as a chromosome. As telophase begins, a visible nuclear membrane begins to form around each set of chromosomes. In the last step, division of the cytoplasm occurs, and its contents are split into two daughter cells.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. To prepare, check your instructor’s directions, study the mitosis poster, and set up the microscope. In the activity, you will examine a microscope slide on low power, then on high power, before sketching or photographing cells in cell cycle phases. You will then count the number of cells in each phase for three sections of the slide. Next, you will calculate the total number of cells in each phase, as well as the total cells counted, to then calculate the percentage of time the organism spends in each phase. You will repeat this activity for both slides in the slide set.

You will repeat this activity for both slides in the slide set.

Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Ensure that any broken or discarded microscope slides are disposed of properly. Put them in a hard-sided container (such as a small, sturdy cardboard box) before placing them in the household trash.

Read about how to care for the slides used with your microscope.
How to care for the slides used with your microscopeWatch the following video to learn how to take a picture through your microscope.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of these phases or subphases accounts for about 90% of the cell cycle?
Which is the only subphase of interphase where chromosome duplication occurs?
As chromosomes condense in prophase, the region where the chromatids connect shrinks to a narrow area.  What is this area called?
During which phase of mitosis does the nuclear envelope disappear and the microtubules extending from each centrosome begin invading the nuclear area to interact with the condensed chromosomes?
Which of the following statements best describes the end of anaphase?

options.text: The cell begins to elongate, its two poles having equal collections of chromosomes.
The chromosomes in the cell become less tightly coiled.
The nuclear envelope disappears in the cell and the chromosomes are condensed.
A cell plate forms in the middle of the cell to eventually form a new cell wall.
The mitotic spindle of the cell begins to form outside the nucleus.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following terms defines the division of one nucleus into two genetically identical nuclei?
Into which of the following containers could you place your broken or discarded microscope slides for safe disposal in the household trash?
Which of the following best describes the difference in cytokinesis between animal and plant cells?

options.text: An animal is pinched in two; a plant cell is divided by a cell plate.
An animal cell is pushed apart; a plant cell is pulled apart.
An animal cell completes this phase twice as fast as a plant cell.
An animal cell completes this phase before telophase rather than after telophase.
An animal cell divides into four cells; a plant cell divides into two cells.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the Procedure before beginning.
You may print these templates to organize your drawings for this investigation.
Study the <button class='glossary-text'>Mitosis</button> poster, examining the characteristics of each of the phases of mitosis in plant and animal cells.
Prepare a clean work area.
Set up the microscope.

As a refresher before beginning the activity, review the parts of the microscope and how to operate it. If your instructor asks you to calculate total magnification, use the formula below. A microscope with an ocular lens with a magnification of 10× and an objective lens with a magnification of 40× has a total magnification of 400×.

Total magnification = (eyepiece lens power) x (objective lens power)

In Activity 1, you will observe cells from an onion root tip and whitefish blastocyst under the microscope, and sketch or photograph the phases of <button class='glossary-text'>mitosis</button> in these plant and animal cells. Then, for each slide, you will count the number of cells in each phase of mitosis and calculate the percentage of time spent in each phase for each organism.
Place the onion root tip slide on the microscope stage. Secure the slide with the stage clips.
Examine the onion root tip slide under low power. Note the appearance of the cells.
Switch to the high-power objective lens (40×).
Locate a cell in each phase of the cell cycle and draw the cell. Take a photo of your drawings. If you are not using the drawing template, include 2-3 drawings in each photo.
While viewing one section of the slide, count the number of different cells that appear to be in each phase of the cell cycle and record these numbers in Data Table 1.
Move the slide on the stage in order to observe another section of the slide. Repeat step 5 for 2 additional sections of the slide.
Switch to the low-power objective lens and remove the onion root tip slide.

Add the total number of cells per phase in each column and record this in the “Total per phase” section. Then, add the total number of cells and record it in the “Total cells” section. Then calculate the percentage of the number of cells in each phase by taking the total number of cells per phase and dividing it by the total number of cells and then multiplying by 100.
Place the whitefish <button class='glossary-text'>mitosis</button> slide on the microscope stage and secure with the stage clips.
Examine the whitefish cells under low power. Note differences between the animal cells and the plant cells observed previously.
Switch to the high-power objective lens (40×).
Locate a cell in each phase of the cell cycle and draw the cell. Take a photo of your drawings. If you are not using the drawing template, include 2-3 drawings in each photo.
While viewing one section of the slide, count the number of different cells that appear to be in each phase of the cell cycle and record these numbers in Data Table 2.
Move the slide on the stage in order to observe another section of the slide. Repeat step 13 for 2 additional sections of the slide.
Switch to the low-power objective lens and remove the whitefish slide.

Add the total number of cells per phase in each column and record this in the “Total per phase” section. Then, add the total number of cells and record it in the “Total cells” section. Then calculate the percentage of the number of cells in each phase by taking the total number of cells per phase and dividing it by the total number of cells and then multiplying by 100.

text: Use Carolina’s iPad<sup>®</sup>/iPhone<sup>®</sup> Plant Histology app to review and study the phases of <button class='glossary-text'>mitosis</button> and meiosis in plant cells.

pageData.subTitle: Plant Histology iTunes<sup>®</sup> App
pageData.text: Plant Histology ©Carolina Biological Supply Company. The Plant Histology app features images from Carolina’s best microscope slides highlighting plant mitosis and meiosis and comparing monocots and dicots, which are also pictured macroscopically. Meiosis is shown in the lily anther and the ovulary. This reference app includes interactive practice sections and is useful for quick review as well as initial learning.Plant Histology iTunes® App

text: Use Carolina’s iPad<sup>®</sup>/iPhone<sup>®</sup> Animal Histology app to review and study the phases of mitosis and meiosis in animal cells.

pageData.subTitle: Animal Histology iTunes<sup>®</sup> App
pageData.text: Animal Histology ©Carolina Biological Supply Company. The Animal Histology app features images from some of Carolina’s best microscope slides, including mitosis in a fish embryo and detailed vertebrate histology. The histology photos cover major variations of the four basic tissue types. The text describes each tissue’s function and location. Because this reference app includes interactive practice sections, it is useful for quick review as well as initial learning.Animal Histology iTunes® App

text: Place the slides back in the slide box provided.
Turn off the microscope, and, if applicable, disconnect the power source. Cover the microscope.

How to Take a Picture Through a Microscope

data.title: Anaphase
data.content: The third subphase of mitosis; during this phase, the two sister chromatids of each chromosome separate and are pulled, centromere first, toward opposite cell poles by attached spindle fibers, and the cell begins to elongate

data.title: Cell division
data.content: The process of reproducing cells; it functions in reproduction, growth, and repair of an organism

data.title: Cytokinesis
data.content: The division of the cytoplasm and its contents into two daughter cells; this process ususally overlaps the telophase mitotic subphase

data.title: G1 phase
data.content: The first of the three sub-phases of interphase; it is characterized by cell growth and the synthesis of mRNA and proteins; the  “G” stands for “gap”

data.title: G2 phase
data.content: The last of the three subphases of interphase; it is characterized by the synthesis of the proteins necessary for chromosome sorting and cell division; the “G” stands for “gap”

data.title: Interphase
data.content: The phase of the cell cycle that prepares the cell for nuclear division; during this phase, DNA is replicated, the cell rapidly grows and produces organelles, and proteins are created

data.title: Metaphase
data.content: The second subphase of mitosis; during this phase, the chromosomes are pushed by attached spindle fibers into a line along an imaginary plane at the center of the cell

data.title: Mitosis
data.content: The phase of the cell cycle during which actual cell division takes place; it gives rise to genetically identical cells in which the total number of chromosomes is maintained; also called M phase

data.title: Prometaphase
data.content: An intermediary subphase between prophase and metaphase of mitosis; during this phase, the nuclear envelope disappears and the microtubules extending from each centromere can interact with the condensed chromosomes

data.title: Prophase
data.content: The first subphase of mitosis; during this phase, replicated DNA condenses into chromosomes that consist of two identical sister chromatids bound by a centromere

data.title: S phase
data.content: The second of the three sub-phases of interphase; it is characterized by DNA replication forming identical sister chromatids; the “S” stands for “synthesis”

data.title: Telophase
data.content: The last subphase of mitosis; during this phase, a visible nuclear membrane begins to form around each set of chromosomes, which decondense
